H0.text: Meter is the most appropriate unit of measurement for expressing the distance between the Milky Way galaxy and other galaxies.

H1.text: Kilometer is the most appropriate unit of measurement to express the distance between the Milky Way galaxy and other galaxies.

H2.text: Light-year is the most appropriate unit of measurement to express the distance between the Milky Way galaxy and other galaxies.

H3.text: Astronomical unit is the most appropriate unit of measurement to express the distance between the Milky Way galaxy and other galaxies.

A4.text: Distances to objects such as quasars and the Sloan Great Wall run into the billions of light-years.

A5.text: The unit most commonly used in professional astronomy is the parsec.

A6.text: Eclipsing binaries can give direct distance estimates to galaxies up to about 3 million parsecs (3 Mpc).

A7.text: Distances based on direct measurements are available only out to about a thousand parsecs.

A8.text: The Milky Way has an estimated diameter of 26.8 ± 1.1 kiloparsecs (87,400 ± 3,600 light-years)

A9.text: Typically, a void spans a distance of 7–30 megaparsecs.

A10.text: the mean free path of a photon in intergalactic space is about 10^23 km, or 10 billion light years.
